poem:
Title: "Leafing Through Fatherhood"

On bookuned pages, ladies ink a father's tale, 
Where men oft overlook, deem trivial, frail.
This homely realm, a kingdom deemed mundane,
Hints Cyril Connolly, held no poetic gain.
Yet within the cradle's quiet lull and child's shout,
Rest silent stories, as sunrise cast out. 
Be not dismissive, heed the domestic beat -
in fatherhood's cadence, art and life meet.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Five of the best books about fatherhood When I tried to winnow down my favourite books about fatherhood, it was a surprise to realise how many of the novels on my list were written by women. What is it with dudes and the domestic? Where did the idea come from that that part of life is dull, beneath artistic notice? We have Cyril Connolly to thank for the old edict that there is “no more". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
